segments.text: Ping-pong must be the top-ranking popular sport in China . It seems to me in every school , factory , army unit , or residential area , men and women , young and old , are swinging paddles .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: You got it ! In a sense , it has become a byword for Chinese sport .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: What do you think might be the source of its popularity ?
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: I think its critical advantage lies in its low cost . All you need is a racket , a table and a light celluloid ball . Tables are usually available in public recreation areas , like finest rooms , and outdoor playgrounds ...
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: And sometimes a substitute table can be made out of a few desks .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: Put it there ! In senior high schools , we used to play on desks in the classroom , when no vacant tables were available . Likewise , the racket may take a variety of forms , too.Anything that resembles a racket , from a plank to cardboard or even a hardcover book , may be used as a racket .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: Haha , these are very good inventions . All these speak the public's fondness for the sport
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: Yeah , the sport is affordable and accessible to every Tom , Dick and Jane in this developing country . No wonder even the state leaders are known to be keen on it .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: I know President Hu Into likes playing ping-pong .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: Actually , he excels in it . Chairman Mao , too , encouraged the whole nation to play ping-pong as a part of the nationwide body building campaign .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: I see . There was also the famous ping pong diplomacy , wasn't there ?
segments.speaker: S1
